author: yblue19
content:
I spent a bit time reading optimistic rollup but I couldn't understand why fraud proof is useful.. Still a complete n00b so highly appreciate if someone could point me to the right resources.

I assume fraud means some invalid transaction (e.g. a hacker spoof a tx to double spend my USDC elsewhere on L2). 

If there is no fraud, no one really need fraud proof.. If there is indeed a fraud, it takes up to 7 days to be detected. When the fraud is detected, what's going to happen? Revert L2 to pre-fraud block? But that seems both unlikely and ineffective. There are many other transactions unrelated to the fraud committed after the fraud tx that would have to be reverted. Even if everyone is ok to revert everything, the money is likely already gone - withdrawal to an CEX onramp or swapped away to another L1 via liquidity bridge.. Yes it didn't get committed to L1 Mainnet but that seems no longer useful.. Anyway, I'm quite puzzled.

author: treyzania
content: No if there's no fraud it takes the grace period for it to be locked in, if there is then it can be proved immediately

author: treyzania
content: the "optimisic" part is that the "compactified" txs data is mostly ignored unless there is fraud, the new state root is marked as pending and that's it
